elements.text: Yes, we mentioned it at the last R Contribution Working Group meeting, but at that point GSoD 2022 hadn't been announced - I see it now has (perhaps you already saw this Rachitt):

text:
Switching back to main channel as this is the only conversation going on at the moment! The GSoD 2022 page for the R project is here: <https://github.com/rstats-gsod/gsod2022/wiki|https://github.com/rstats-gsod/gsod2022/wiki>. We had a couple of tentative ideas suggested over the past year which are in the issues of that repo. I don't think either gained much support. There is more demand to update the R Development Guide (<https://contributor.r-project.org/rdevguide/|https://contributor.r-project.org/rdevguide/>) - there are several issues on the repo (<https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues|https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues>). I would highlight:
• More information (a new chapter?) on tests for base R (<https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues/28|https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues/28>)
• Describing a git workflow for testing proposed patches (<https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues/23|https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues/23>)
• Novice-friendly instructions on installing R from source (<https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues/33|https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues/33> - besides the official <https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-admin.html|https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-admin.html>)

text:
Would it be alright if I asking these as a question on the devel mailing list?

We could learn more what the community wants and perhaps float a vote for the different ideas?

Once we understand where we need work, we can start defining project scope which can help the writers who wish to work with us.

text: The R project website is currently built from markdown files using pandoc (see svn here: <https://svn.r-project.org/R-project-web/trunk/>). This is low maintenance with minimal infrastructure (dependencies), so I expect R core would be reluctant to change anything there.

elements.text: The R project website is currently built from markdown files using pandoc (see svn here:
). This is low maintenance with minimal infrastructure (dependencies), so I expect R core would be reluctant to change anything there.

text: This reminded me about changes that would be nice on the CRAN website though and I added a new issue about that: <https://github.com/rstats-gsod/gsod2022/issues/4>

attachments.text:
One issue is to convert the CRAN website to a more modern and accessible format: <https://github.com/RConsortium/r-repositories-wg/issues/5#issuecomment-1021697261|RConsortium/r-repositories-wg#5 (comment)>.

This might not make a documentation project in itself. However, possibly documentation surrounding CRAN may be helpful, e.g.

• Documenting specifications of the CRAN check systems
• Documenting common reasons for rejecting packages submissions and how to fix them. A small example that I helped with recently: message from CRAN
    
    > "Packages in Suggests should only be used conditionally on their availability, as they may not be installed and the package should not fail in that case (particularly not in examples nor tests)."
    
    The solution is documented in <https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-exts.html#Suggested-packages|https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-exts.html#Suggested-packages>, but a problem & solution style documentation would be more helpful to novice developers.
attachments.title: <https://github.com/rstats-gsod/gsod2022/issues/4|#4 CRAN-related project>

elements.text: This reminded me about changes that would be nice on the CRAN website though and I added a new issue about that:

text: I've put the dev guide idea in an issue here: <https://github.com/rstats-gsod/gsod2022/issues/3>

attachments.fallback: <https://github.com/rstats-gsod/gsod2022/issues/3|#3 Further work on R Development Guide>
attachments.text:
There are several issues on the <https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues|repo> for the <https://contributor.r-project.org/rdevguide/|R Development Guide> that could be addressed in a GSoD project.

I would highlight:

• Add chapter on translations (<https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues/34|r-devel/rdevguide#34>)
• More information (a new chapter?) on tests for base R (<https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues/28|r-devel/rdevguide#28>)
• Describing a git workflow for testing proposed patches (<https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues/23|r-devel/rdevguide#23>)
• Novice-friendly instructions on installing R from source (<https://github.com/r-devel/rdevguide/issues/33|r-devel/rdevguide#33> - as a companion to the official documentation <https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-admin.html|https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-admin.html>)

These extensions, plus addressing the smaller miscellaneous issues could easily form a GSoD project.
attachments.title: <https://github.com/rstats-gsod/gsod2022/issues/3|#3 Further work on R Development Guide>

elements.text: I've put the dev guide idea in an issue here:

text: Also added another idea based around accessibility, pulling together some ideas from the Forwards accessibility team and this Slack space: <https://github.com/rstats-gsod/gsod2022/issues/5>

attachments.text:
The Forwards accessibility team have suggested many changes that would improve accessibility, e.g.

• dark mode on R project websites and/or help files
• HTML vs PDF vignettes
    • This could be tools to support almost automated conversion, helping CRAN developers to do it themselves. I think some Bioconductor folks did some work on this, I will add the link when I have a chance to dig it up
    • Alternatively, contributing to packages to replace the PDF vignette with an HTML one
• HTML package manual vs PDF reference manual
    • This already exists for every package but is hard to find. Adding a field to DESCRIPTION or replacing PDF in the Reference Manual field with a link such as <https://search.r-project.org/CRAN/refmans/survival/html/00Index.html|https://search.r-project.org/CRAN/refmans/survival/html/00Index.html> would help people to find this and prioritise HTML over PDF.

There are other places where HTML could be used instead of PDF, but the above would not require much to change in the core codebase, so perhaps would be good to start with.
attachments.title: <https://github.com/rstats-gsod/gsod2022/issues/5|#5 Accessibility related project>

text:
I'm surprised by that comment, the policy doesn't say anything about suggested not failing:
> A package listed in ‘Suggests’ or ‘Enhances’ should be used conditionally in examples or tests if it cannot straightforwardly be installed on the major R platforms. (‘Writing R Extensions’ recommends that they are _always_ used conditionally.)

elements.text: I'm surprised by that comment, the policy doesn't say anything about suggested not failing:

A package listed in ‘Suggests’ or ‘Enhances’ should be used conditionally in examples or tests if it cannot straightforwardly be installed on the major R platforms. (‘Writing R Extensions’ recommends that they are
always
used conditionally.)

text: I posted some analysis on common problems that make packages archived on my blog <https://llrs.dev/post/2021/12/07/reasons-cran-archivals/> hope this helps, I also have some other content/ideas that might be helpful  to avoid having problems with packages on CRAN.

attachments.fallback: B101nfo: Reasons why packages are archived on CRAN | B101nfo
attachments.text: Most frequent reason is due to the package not fixed on time, followed by depending on packages archived and policy violation.
attachments.title: Reasons why packages are archived on CRAN | B101nfo
